The email arrived at three-seventeen in the afternoon, a time usually reserved for the dregs of lukewarm tea and the slow, sinking feeling that another day had mostly been wasted. It landed in Arthur Penhaligon’s inbox with no fanfare, a digital dove of peace amidst a flock of vultures advertising discounted office supplies and seminars on probate law. The subject line was stark, simple. ‘Voice of Tomorrow – Grand Finalist.’

Arthur stared. He was a solicitor. That’s what the brass plate said. Arthur Penhaligon. A name too grand for the peeling paint of the doorframe it was screwed to, a name that suggested oak-panelled walls and leather-bound books, not the cramped, second-floor office above a Greggs in the heart of Dudley. The air in his office smelled of aging paper, dust, and the faint, lingering ghost of a steak bake from lunchtime. Piles of conveyancing files, bound in pink legal tape that was slowly losing its will to live, slumped against the walls like weary soldiers.

A solicitor. He dealt in facts, in clauses, in the dreary, black-and-white architecture of the law. But the email. The email was pure, Technicolor fantasy.

His finger, trembling slightly, nudged the mouse. The click was unnaturally loud in the quiet room. The body of the message opened, a block of text that seemed to hum with a strange energy. ‘Dear Mr Penhaligon, Following your sensational performance in the semi-final stage, we are delighted to inform you that you have been selected as one of the twelve Grand Finalists for this year’s Voice of Tomorrow competition…’

The words blurred. Sensational performance. Grand Finalist. London Palladium.

A sound escaped his throat, something between a gasp and a strangled yelp. He shoved his chair back, the cheap casters screaming in protest against the scuffed linoleum. The chair collided with a tower of files pertaining to the acrimonious divorce of a Mr and Mrs Hargreaves. The tower swayed, held its breath for a moment, and then surrendered, cascading across the floor in a papery waterfall of bitter accusations and financial disputes. Arthur didn't notice.

He was going to London. He was going to sing on the stage of the Palladium. The same stage that had held Frank Sinatra, Judy Garland, Nat King Cole. His heroes. The voices that had been the soundtrack to his lonely life, the velvet-smooth antidote to the jagged edges of reality. He, Arthur Penhaligon, solicitor of this parish, a man whose professional life was a symphony of other people’s miseries, was going to stand in that hallowed spotlight. The joy was a Catherine wheel, spitting sparks in the grey filing cabinet of his soul.

“Everything alright in there, Arthur? Sounded like you were wrestling a badger.”

The voice came through the frosted glass of his office door. Brenda. His secretary, his gatekeeper, his anchor to the real world for the past fifteen years. She was a woman built for comfort and practicality, who viewed Arthur’s singing ambitions with the same affectionate scepticism she reserved for fad diets and politicians' promises.

He wrenched the door open, the email still glowing on the monitor behind him like a holy relic. He was grinning, a wide, foolish, face-splitting grin he hadn’t used since he was a boy. “Brenda. Brenda, you are not going to believe this.”

She stood there, a mug of tea in one hand, a digestive biscuit poised for dunking in the other. Her eyebrows, meticulously plucked into two surprised arches, rose a fraction of an inch higher. “Let me guess. The Henderson sale hasn’t fallen through after all.”

“Better! Infinitely, immeasurably better!” He grabbed her by the shoulders, a gesture of familiarity so rare it caused her to slosh tea onto her hand. “I’m in. The final. The Voice of Tomorrow. I’m in!”

Brenda looked from his beaming face to the chaos of the Hargreaves file on the floor, then back again. A slow smile spread across her own face, crinkling the corners of her eyes. “Oh, Arthur. That’s… well, isn’t that just bostin’?”

It was the highest praise. Bostin’. The Black Country seal of genuine approval. It made the whole thing feel real. He wasn’t just a fantasist in a dusty office anymore. He was a Grand Finalist.

He spent the rest of the afternoon in a fugue state. He tried to redraft a will, but the legalese kept morphing into song lyrics. ‘I bequeath my entire estate to the shimmering high C I’m going to hit on the final note of ‘My Way’.’ He answered the phone to a client and nearly sang his response down the line. Brenda fielded most of the calls, explaining his distraction with a series of inventive excuses ranging from a sudden migraine to a complex legal conundrum that required his full, monk-like concentration.

At five o’clock, she poked her head around the door. “I’m off now, Pavarotti. Don’t stay up all night rehearsing, you’ve got that boundary dispute first thing.” She paused, her hand on the doorframe. “I mean it, Arthur. I’m really chuffed for you. Knock ‘em dead.”

After she left, the silence of the office descended again, but it was a different kind of silence now. It was the quiet of anticipation, the held breath before the first note. He stood at the window, looking down at the Friday evening traffic crawling through Dudley. The streetlights flickered on, casting a jaundiced glow on the wet pavement. Usually, he saw the grime, the weariness of the town. Tonight, he saw a backdrop. He saw people in those cars, in those buses, hurrying home to their lives, and he felt a strange, benevolent pity for them. They didn’t know. They didn’t know that a star was about to be born, right here, above a Greggs.

He didn't go straight home. He couldn’t. The energy was too much to be contained within the four walls of his small flat. He walked, his worn leather-soled shoes slapping a cheerful rhythm on the paving stones. He walked past the marketplace, where vendors were packing away their unsold fruit and knock-off handbags. He walked towards the hulking silhouette of Dudley Castle on its hill, a stone sentinel watching over the town. He felt like a king surveying his kingdom.

His steps led him, as they often did, to The Tilted Barrel, a pub tucked away down a side street, all dark wood and the smell of stale beer. It was here, on a small, scuffed patch of floor they called a stage, that he’d honed his craft. Every other Thursday, open mic night. He’d started years ago, a nervous man in a slightly-too-large suit, clutching the microphone stand as if it were a life raft. He’d closed his eyes and sung, pouring all the frustration of his dead-end job, all the loneliness of his empty evenings, into the smoky air. And a funny thing had happened. People had listened. The chatter had died down. The clinking of glasses had softened. For three and a half minutes, he could hold a room. He could make them feel something.

That feeling was a drug. More potent than any pint. It was the feeling he had chased all the way to the Voice of Tomorrow auditions in Birmingham, queuing for hours in the rain with teenagers in tracksuits and sixty-year-old women who thought they were the next Shirley Bassey. And he’d beaten them. He’d sung ‘A House Is Not A Home’ in a room with three bored-looking producers and made the youngest one, a girl with purple hair and a nose ring, wipe a tear from her eye. That was his power.

He ordered a pint of Banks’s and took it to his usual corner table. He didn't speak to anyone. He just sat there, nursing the beer, the joy a warm, steady glow in his chest. He saw it all. The train to London. A smart hotel room, maybe with a little fridge for a bottle of champagne. The sharp suit he’d have to buy. He’d need new shoes. And a tie. A proper silk tie. He’d walk out onto that stage, the lights would hit him, and the orchestra would begin. An orchestra! He’d only ever sung to a backing track on a tinny PA system. The thought of real, live strings swelling behind him made his heart ache with longing.

He finished his pint, the glow turning into a giddy buzz. It was time to go home. Time to make it official. Time to book the ticket to his new life.

His flat was on the third floor of a Victorian house that had been carved up into mean-little apartments. It was tidy, in a cluttered sort of way. His law books shared shelf space with biographies of crooners. A vintage, non-functional Shure microphone sat on his mantelpiece like a religious icon. The place was a shrine to his two conflicting lives: the drab reality and the glorious dream.

He kicked off his shoes, shrugged off his jacket, and sat down at the small dining table that doubled as his home office. He opened his laptop, the screen illuminating his face in the dark room. The competition was in two weeks. A Friday. He’d have to take two days off work. Brenda would cope. The world of conveyancing could wait.

He navigated to the train booking website. Dudley Port to London Euston. Return. A little thrill went through him as he typed the destination. London. The big smoke. He selected the dates, a Thursday morning departure, a Saturday afternoon return. He’d give himself a day to recover, to bask in the victory. The price loaded.

Arthur stared at the screen. £168.50.

One hundred and sixty-eight pounds and fifty pence. For a train ticket. An ‘off-peak saver return,’ it said, as if that were a kindness. The number seemed absurd, a typo. He cleared the search and tried again. The same figure appeared. It was malevolent. It was a bouncer at the door of the greatest party of his life, folding its arms and shaking its head.

A prickle of unease, cold and sharp, pierced the warm bubble of his joy. Okay. It was a lot. But it was manageable. It was an investment. He’d need a hotel, too. He opened another tab, a budget hotel chain he’d heard of. A windowless room near the station. Two nights. £220.

He added the numbers in his head. £168.50 plus £220. That was £388.50. And he’d need to eat. And get around London. And what about that suit? The silk tie? The new shoes? The figure in his head began to spin, rising like the national debt. It was easily over five hundred pounds. Maybe six hundred, to be safe.

Arthur took a deep breath. It was fine. This was what savings were for. He was a solicitor, for God’s sake. A professional man. He wasn't destitute. He opened a new tab, his online banking portal. He typed in his credentials, his fingers suddenly clumsy. He clicked to view his current account.

The balance appeared. £87.14.

He clicked on his savings account, the one he’d labelled ‘Rainy Day Fund’. The one he occasionally dipped into for a rare Sinatra vinyl or a new pair of speakers he couldn’t afford.

The balance was £21.30.

The numbers didn’t compute. He looked from the train fare to his bank balance and back again. The joy that had filled him up all day, that had made the world shine, drained out of him in a sudden, brutal rush, leaving him hollow and cold. It was the feeling a man has when he wakes from a beautiful dream to find himself in a prison cell.

He had a hundred and eight pounds and forty-four pence to his name. The final was in fourteen days. His next payday was three weeks away.

He sat there in the dark, the glow of the laptop screen painting a cruel, mocking light on his face. The London Palladium. The orchestra. The spotlight. It was all there, a perfect, shimmering mirage just across the desert. And he was going to die of thirst before he could reach it. He didn’t have the train fare. The ridiculous, mundane, pathetic train fare. He wasn’t going to be scuppered by a rival singer, by a sore throat, by a crisis of confidence. He was going to be defeated by the Great Western Railway pricing structure.

A laugh bubbled up in his chest, a dry, rattling, horrible sound. He, Arthur Penhaligon, a man of the law, a man who navigated the complex currents of the British legal system for a living, was too poor to get a train to London. He put his head in his hands, the laughter turning into a single, choked sob. The dream wasn't just fraying at the edges. It had just been garrotted with a piece of pink legal tape.For a long time, he didn't move. The single sob hung in the airless room, an epitaph for a dream that had lasted barely five hours. The laptop screen flickered, automatically dimming, as if embarrassed by the raw, pathetic misery it was illuminating. The numbers remained, burned onto his retinas: £168.50, £220, £87.14, £21.30. They were the four horsemen of his own personal apocalypse, trampling his glorious vision into the dust of his threadbare carpet. He had spent his entire adult life navigating the dense thicket of financial legalese for other people – probate tax, capital gains, stamp duty land tax – yet he had failed, catastrophically, to manage his own. The irony was so bitter it made his teeth ache.

His professional life was a slow-motion slide into obscurity. He’d taken over the firm from his father, a man who had commanded respect and a steady stream of affluent clients. But under Arthur’s stewardship, the good clients had drifted away, replaced by the bitter dregs of society’s disputes: neighbours warring over fence posts, small businesses chasing unpaid invoices, and the endless, soul-sapping carousel of small-town divorces like the Hargreaveses. He charged too little and worked too slowly, paralyzed by a crippling empathy for his clients’ woes. The peeling paint on his office door wasn't a quirk; it was a warning sign he had ignored for years. He wasn’t a charmingly old-fashioned solicitor; he was a failing one.

With a surge of desperate energy, he turned back to the laptop. There had to be a way. A solicitor's mind is trained to find loopholes, to seek out solutions where none seem to exist. He clicked through to his banking app again, navigating to the overdraft section. ‘Limit: £500. Currently Used: £500.’ He’d been living in it for months, a permanent state of being five hundred pounds behind the world. A credit card, then. He had one, somewhere in his wallet. He dug it out and logged into the provider's website. The balance glared at him, a four-figure sum he’d amassed buying essential legal texts and covering a disastrous boiler replacement last winter. The 'available credit' was a mocking £12.50. Not even enough for a taxi to the station.

His search history became a litany of desperation. ‘Quick cash loans.’ ‘Sell things for money.’ ‘How to get to London for free.’ He recoiled in horror from the payday loan websites, their cheerful branding and promises of instant cash barely masking the predatory interest rates that made his legally-trained stomach clench. He imagined trying to explain that to a judge. ‘Yes, your Honour, I funded my singing career with a 1,200% APR loan.’ He would be a laughing stock. The shame of it all began to wash over him, hot and suffocating. What would he tell Brenda? That her faith in him, her genuine, ‘bostin’’ joy, had been for nothing? He pictured her face, the disappointment behind her kind eyes. It was worse than the thought of his own failure.

He pushed the laptop away, the light from the screen suddenly unbearable. He stood and walked to the window, staring out into the blackness of his own reflection. The joyful, grinning fool from a few hours earlier was gone, replaced by a pale, hollow-eyed man on the wrong side of forty. This was it, then. The high point of his life would be a single email, a brief, tantalising glimpse of a world he wasn’t equipped to enter. He would have to decline. He would have to write back, citing ‘unforeseen personal circumstances,’ the bland, universal code for a life that had crumbled. He would go back to his dusty office, to the Hargreaves file, and the ghost of steak bakes, and the Voice of Tomorrow would become another bitter anecdote he told himself in the lonely quiet of the evenings.

His gaze drifted from the window, across the cluttered living room, searching for something, anything, to anchor him. It fell upon the shelves flanking the fireplace. They were his pride and joy, a carefully curated history of the voices that had shaped him. Row upon row of vinyl records. Not just any records. First pressings. Limited editions. There was the UK mono pressing of ‘Sinatra at the Sands’, the one with the slight printing error on the sleeve that made it rarer. There was a copy of ‘Judy at Carnegie Hall’ signed – supposedly – by one of the orchestra’s viola players. There was his complete collection of Nat King Cole’s Capitol recordings, each vinyl sleeve as familiar to him as the back of his own hand. These weren't just music; they were his friends. They were the council of velvet-voiced ghosts he consulted on lonely nights.

The thought formed, unwelcome and ugly. Sell them. The idea was a physical violation, like being asked to sell a kidney. He had spent years hunting them down in dusty second-hand shops, on eBay, at record fairs. Each one held a memory, a story. To part with them would be to tear out a part of his own history, to silence the choir that lived in his flat. He reached out and ran a finger along the spine of a Dean Martin LP. The plastic crackled comfortingly under his touch. How could he?

But then, his eyes moved from the records to the mantelpiece, to the gleaming, chrome Shure microphone. And beyond it, in his mind’s eye, he saw the stage of the Palladium. He saw the spotlight. He heard the hush of the crowd, the first, swelling notes from a real, living orchestra. What was the point of worshipping the relics of the past if you refused the chance to make your own future? What was the point of owning Sinatra’s voice on vinyl if you were too scared to use your own? The choice was brutal, but it was clear. The ghosts on his shelf had had their time in the spotlight. Now, it was his turn. He took a deep, shuddering breath, the first one that didn’t feel like it was laced with broken glass. He would sell them. He would sell them all if he had to.The decision, once made, settled in his bones not as a comfort but as a cold, hard ballast. The frantic despair of the previous hour solidified into a grim resolve. There was no more time for weeping. Weeping wouldn’t buy a train ticket. He moved with the stiff, unnatural purpose of a man walking to his own execution. From the bottom of his wardrobe, he pulled out two large, empty cardboard boxes that had once held printer paper. They felt flimsy, inadequate coffins for what he was about to bury. He knelt before the shelves, the altar of his private religion, and began the terrible triage.

His hands, which could draft a conveyance with steady precision, trembled as they touched the record sleeves. He started with the duplicates, the lesser pressings, the albums he liked but didn't love. It felt like choosing which fingers to sacrifice to save the hand. But the pile grew slowly, its monetary value a pittance against the mountain of his need. He knew, with a certainty that settled like lead in his gut, that the outer circle wouldn’t be enough. He had to go deeper. He had to cut into the heart of the collection. He slid out 'Sinatra at the Sands'. He could feel the ghost of the crowd noise, the clink of glasses, the sheer, swaggering genius of the man captured in the grooves. He’d bought it for a steal at a car boot sale in Stourbridge, the seller completely unaware of the rarity of the mono pressing. Placing it in the box felt like a betrayal.

One by one, his friends went into the cardboard tomb. The raw emotion of 'Judy at Carnegie Hall'. The honey-smooth perfection of Nat King Cole’s 'Love is the Thing'. A rare Sarah Vaughan import he’d had shipped from the States. Each one was a memory, a specific lonely evening made bearable, a moment of transcendence in his cramped, ordinary life. He worked mechanically, trying to shut down the part of his brain that was screaming in protest. He created a second, smaller pile on the floor: the absolute untouchables. A signed Tom Jones album his father had given him. A first-pressing of Dusty in Memphis. His very first Sinatra record, the one that had started it all, its cover worn smooth by the touch of his teenage hands. Looking at the meagre pile of survivors and the two burgeoning boxes for sale, he knew even this was a fantasy. He needed every pound he could get. With a final, soul-crushing wrench, he took ‘Dusty in Memphis’ and gently placed it on top of the others.

He slept in fits and starts, his dreams a chaotic montage of emptying shelves and silent turntables. He woke on Saturday morning to a grey, drizzly dawn that perfectly matched his mood. The flat felt cavernous. The silence where the music used to be was deafening. He taped up the boxes with a grim finality, the screech of the tape gun like a cry of pain. Lifting them was a struggle; the weight of his sacrificed past was considerable. He couldn't carry them both on the bus. He had to call a taxi, the first irony of many. The fare was another small bite out of a fund that didn’t yet exist.

The taxi dropped him outside a narrow, grubby-fronted shop on a backstreet a few miles away. The sign, in faded, peeling gold letters, read ‘Revolution Records’. It was the only serious second-hand vinyl shop for miles, run by a man named Barry, a fearsome gatekeeper of musical knowledge and a notoriously hard negotiator. The bell above the door gave a tired jingle as Arthur entered, the boxes bumping awkwardly against the frame. The shop smelled of damp, patchouli oil, and the sweet, decaying scent of a million cardboard sleeves. It was a dragon’s hoard, and Arthur was here to offer up his own treasure in tribute.

Barry was perched on a stool behind the counter, a bald, rotund man in a faded Led Zeppelin t-shirt that was losing a valiant battle with his belly. He was peering at a record sleeve through a pair of spectacles perched on the end of his nose. He didn't look up immediately, letting Arthur stand there and stew in the awkward silence. Finally, he sighed, as if the effort of acknowledging a customer was a great personal trial. “Help you?” he grunted.

“I… I have some records I’d like to sell,” Arthur said, his voice sounding thin and reedy. He gestured at the boxes at his feet.

Barry’s eyes flicked down to the boxes, then back up to Arthur’s face. He had the weary, predatory gaze of a man who had seen it all: grieving widows clearing out their husbands' collections, young men selling their fathers' LPs for drug money, and countless desperate souls like Arthur, trying to turn passion into currency. “Let’s have a look, then,” he said, his tone suggesting he was already bored. Arthur heaved the first box onto the counter. Barry began to flip through the contents, his movements practiced and swift. His expression was unreadable, a mask of professional indifference. Arthur felt a desperate urge to explain, to tell him about the history of each album, the condition, the rarity. But he knew it would be pointless. To Barry, they were just stock.

For ten minutes, the only sound was the soft slither of vinyl sleeves against each other. Barry would occasionally pull one out, scrutinise the surface of the record under the dim light, and grunt. It was torture. Arthur felt like a father watching his children being assessed for slaughter. Finally, Barry pushed the last record back into the box and took off his glasses, polishing them on his t-shirt. “Right. There’s some decent stuff here. A bit mainstream for my usual crowd, but the condition’s good on most of it. I’ll give you two hundred for the lot.”

The number hit Arthur like a punch to the stomach. Two hundred. He needed at least five, probably six. “Two hundred?” he stammered. “But the Sinatra at the Sands is a first mono pressing. And the Sarah Vaughan is a Japanese import. They’re worth more than that on their own.”

Barry gave a humourless chuckle. “They’re worth what someone’s willing to pay for them, mate. I’ve got to make a profit. I’ve got rent to pay. I’m not a charity.” He gestured around the cramped shop. “You see a queue of crooner fans out that door? No. It’s all prog rock and sixties psychedelia these days. I’m doing you a favour taking them off your hands.”

Panic, cold and sharp, began to claw at Arthur’s throat. This couldn’t be it. He couldn’t have sacrificed his entire collection for less than half of what he needed. His training as a solicitor, the part of him that dealt in negotiation and reasoned argument, finally kicked in, overriding the emotional turmoil. “That’s your opening offer,” Arthur said, his voice steadier now. “And it’s a poor one. We both know what’s in these boxes. I’m not asking for online prices, I know you have overheads. But four hundred and fifty. That’s a fair price. It leaves you plenty of room.”

Barry raised an eyebrow, a flicker of grudging respect in his eyes. He hadn’t expected the trembling wreck in the solicitor’s suit to have a backbone. “Four-fifty? You’re dreaming. They’ll sit on the shelves for a year. Three hundred. Final offer. Cash.” He began to turn away, a classic negotiating tactic.

“No,” Arthur said, the word louder than he intended. Barry stopped. Arthur took a breath. “This isn’t just about money for me. I need this money for something. Something that won't wait. It's a one-time chance.” He didn't say what it was, but the raw sincerity in his voice hung in the dusty air. “Four hundred. Not a penny less. For both boxes.”

Barry stared at him for a long moment, his gaze assessing. He was weighing Arthur’s desperation against his own profit margin. He glanced at the ‘Dusty in Memphis’ sleeve peeking out of the box. He sighed, a long, theatrical exhalation of defeat. “You’re a pain in the arse, you are,” he grumbled. “Alright. Four hundred. But you’re taking all the joy out of my Saturday.” He reached under the counter and pulled out a cash box.

He counted out the money in a mixture of twenties and tens, the notes worn and soft. Arthur watched the pile grow on the counter, each note representing a piece of his soul. He stacked the cash into a neat brick and put it in the inside pocket of his jacket, the bulk of it a strange and alien feeling against his chest. He turned and walked out of the shop without looking back at the boxes on the counter. The bell gave the same tired jingle, a sound of closure.

The rain had stopped, but the sky was a blanket of unforgiving grey. Arthur didn’t go home to the echoing silence of his flat. He walked with a determined stride to the public library. He sat at a computer terminal, the warmth of the building a stark contrast to the cold knot in his stomach. He pulled the wad of cash from his pocket, laid it on the desk beside the keyboard, and began to type. He booked the train ticket to London Euston. £168.50. He booked the windowless room in the budget hotel. £220. The total came to £388.50. He was left with eleven pounds and fifty pence, plus the hundred-odd he had in his bank account. It was terrifyingly, laughably little. But it was enough. The confirmation emails landed in his inbox, stark and real. It was done. There was no going back now. He had sold his past for a ticket to the future. Now all he had to do was make sure it was worth it.**Chapter 2**

Returning to the flat was like entering a ransacked tomb. The silence he had left behind that morning had been pregnant with anticipation; this new silence was a void, a hungry, echoing vacuum where his life’s soundtrack used to be. The empty shelves were stark white wounds against the magnolia walls, layered with a faint film of dust that mapped the exact dimensions of the treasures they had once held. Arthur ran his hand along the smooth, vacant wood, the gesture involuntary, a phantom limb reaching for an amputated part of himself. He sat down and opened his laptop, thinking he could play something from an online streaming service, but the tinny, compressed sound that issued from the small speakers was a cruel parody. It was like offering a photograph of a banquet to a starving man. He snapped the laptop shut. He had made his choice. He had traded the ghosts of old legends for the chance to become one, and the silence was the price of admission.

Monday morning arrived with the pitiless clang of an alarm clock. Back in the office, the world seemed determined to remind him of the life he was trying to escape. Brenda had, with her usual quiet efficiency, rescued the Hargreaves file from the floor and reassembled it into a neat, accusatory stack on his desk. The sight of it filled him with a profound weariness. He spent the morning trying to draft a letter regarding a disputed garden wall, but the legal jargon felt like a foreign language. He found himself staring out of the window, his mind a thousand miles away in a London theatre, the words ‘adverse possession’ and ‘party fence wall’ dissolving into the hum of a phantom orchestra. He was a man stranded between two worlds, fully belonging to neither, and the strain of it was beginning to show.

“You look like you’ve been dug up and slapped back together,” Brenda observed, placing his mid-morning tea on the one clear corner of his desk. The manic, face-splitting grin of Friday was gone, replaced by a taut, wired intensity. The dark circles under his eyes spoke of his restless, silent nights. “Still excited?” she asked, her tone gentle, probing.

“Terrified,” Arthur admitted, the honesty of the word surprising even himself. “It’s one thing getting there. It’s another thing entirely to stand up and… be worth it.”

“Oh, stop your nonsense,” she said, her voice firm but kind. “You’ve been worth it every other Thursday at The Tilted Barrel for years. The only thing that’s changed is the post code.” She gave him a look that was equal parts motherly concern and drill sergeant. “Just don’t you go thinking about it too much. You’ll pop a cog.” But he couldn’t stop thinking about it. The thought was a constant, low-frequency hum beneath the surface of his day, a current pulling him inexorably towards his date with destiny.

The evenings were the hardest. The silence of his flat forced him to confront the single most important decision he now had to make: the song. It couldn't just be any song. It had to be the one. It had to be a statement, a three-minute distillation of his entire life, of the hope and the loneliness and the quiet desperation of his existence. It had to justify the empty shelves. He paced the floor of his living room, humming melodies, discarding giants. 'My Way' was too cliché, a karaoke anthem for drunks who thought they were chairmen of the board. He considered the Luther Vandross song that had touched the producer, 'A House is Not a Home', but it felt too plaintive now, too much like a plea. He wasn't pleading anymore. He had paid his way. He was making a demand.

His mind settled, finally, on a saloon song. A story. It was the last number Frank Sinatra would sing in a set, the lights down low, the audience hushed. 'One for My Baby (and One More for the Road)'. It was a song of endings, of last chances, of a man pouring his heart out to the only person who would listen: a bartender in a deserted dive. It was a song about loneliness, but it wasn't self-pitying. It was defiant, weary, and profound. It was Arthur’s truth, set to a heartbreaking melody. This was his story. He was the man in the song, and the London Palladium would be his bar.

With the song chosen, a new, feverish energy took hold of him. He began to practice, not with joy, but with the grim intensity of an athlete training for the Olympics. The acoustics of the flat had changed. Without the densely packed vinyl to absorb the sound, his voice bounced off the bare walls, raw and exposed. It allowed him to hear every flaw, every slight waver, every imperfect breath. He sang the song again and again and again, deconstructing it, rebuilding it, pouring every ounce of his miserable, hopeful life into each syllable. He sang until his throat felt like sandpaper, ignoring the warning signs, pushing through the strain in a panic-fuelled quest for an impossible perfection.

Two days later, he woke up and the voice was gone. Not completely, but it was a shadow of itself, a cracked and raspy whisper. A cold, nauseating panic, far worse than anything he had felt over the money, seized him. He had sold his past and, in his obsessive desperation, had broken the very tool he needed to build his future. He spent the next forty-eight hours in a self-imposed prison of silence, communicating with Brenda via scribbled notes. He drank gallons of honey and lemon tea, the warmth soothing the raw tissues of his throat but doing nothing for the terror in his heart. The silence of his flat was no longer a void; it was a taunt.

The song will wait.” Alistair began to play again, not the song itself, but a simple, almost hymn-like melody, a gentle, instrumental cradle of sound designed not to prompt, but to soothe. He played for several minutes, a quiet, meditative improvisation that slowly, gently, pushed back the tide of Arthur’s grief. He was not just a session musician; he was a healer, using his instrument to mend the broken pieces of the moment. Slowly, Arthur lowered his hand from his face. He took a deep, shuddering breath, then another, his body coming back under his control. He looked at Alistair and nodded, a single, grateful acknowledgement.

He sang not to the microphone or to Julian, but into the past, his voice a quiet, intimate conversation with a ghost. He wasn't telling a story to an audience; he was reliving a memory in the presence of two trusted friends. As he sang of the slow, painful journey up the stairs, his voice was imbued with a profound tenderness, the sound of a son’s love finally finding its expression. When he reached the final three steps, he closed his eyes, his voice dropping to an almost inaudible whisper, every note trembling with the memory of his father’s last words. He sang the final line, a quiet statement of love and loss, and held the last note not for effect, but because he was physically unable to let it go. It hung in the air of Studio Three, a perfect, heartbreaking testament, before finally fading into the most profound silence the room had ever known.

He stood motionless, emotionally and physically spent, leaning his weight on the microphone stand. The silence stretched, deep and unbroken. Alistair sat at the piano, his head bowed, his hands still resting on the keys as if in prayer. Through the control room glass, Arthur could see Julian, his back to the window, one hand rubbing the back of his neck. For a long time, no one moved. No one spoke. The studio had been transformed from a recording space into a sanctuary, holding the sacred, fragile aftermath of a soul laid bare.
